turn.text: --Well, that's what the company asserts, Justice Kennedy, and that would be something that would--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Isn't this going to be a likelihood in a significant number of these early cases?

turn.speaker: irving_l_gornstein
turn.label: Mr. Irving L. Gornstein
turn.text: --Well, this is no longer at the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I don't know what your presumption is based on.

turn.speaker: irving_l_gornstein
turn.label: Mr. Irving L. Gornstein
turn.text: --There's no longer... we're far distant from the time in which this statute was enacted at this point.
If the Court has--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Gornstein.
Mr. Stein, you have 4 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: Relative to the term under, the term under appears 27 times in section 326, the citizen provision of EPCRA.
We assert in our briefs that under simply relates back, identifies the section of the statute that the citizen opportunity refers to.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But isn't it equally reasonable to think that it refers to in compliance with the provisions of, rather than just the statute by name?

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, Ardonesti v. INS says that the term under should be taken from the context of the statute, and the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I don't think we need that case to tell us that.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --Well, in any event--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --what was the name of that case--

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --in the context of this statute, though, I think in the context of the history surrounding the statute, and the context of the way this Court has analyzed citizen suit provisions as being forward-looking, under simply is a relation back.

Again, they... respondent suggests that under means in accordance with, but at section 326(a)(1)(B)(iv), and again in section 321(a)(1)(C), Congress did use the in accordance with formulation, and therefore Congress knows how to say, in accordance with, if it wishes to incorporate the specific provisions of the related-to section, and it knows how to use under, as it did 27 times.
So we think the better reading, as the United Musical Court looked at it.
Under simply relates back, and did not get into what that Court--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --So you think if you filed a statement of emissions that was entirely wrong, all the elements and all the quantities are wrong, you'd... suit would not lie?

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --No, Justice Scalia.
We--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It would have been filed under that provision.

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --The... but it's also--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's just not in compliance with it, that's all.

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --No.
We think that the complete portion of the complete and submit language suffices for that.
A form would certainly not be complete--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's completed.
There's no blank in the whole thing.
He just writes in the wrong elements and the wrong quantities.

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --But we think Congress would not give such an obviously glaring omission in a statute.
The complete language connotes some kind of completeness in terms of proper and accurately complete.
That's what complete seems to me.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But the language certainly is open, and if it's open, why wouldn't it make a lot of sense to say, in the instance where there's some reason to think they'll do it again, they did it before, maybe they'll do it again.
Or they didn't do it before, maybe they won't do it again.
In such a case, it authorizes the suit.

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: It would be inconsistent to apply... if we're talking about under, still, and the timeliness element, it would be inconsistent to apply the timely provisions of section 312 and 313, because Congress had readily available options which it used in other statutes.
It could have said, failure to complete and timely submit.
It could have said, failure to have completed and submitted.
It had many options.
It could have given the opportunity to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, it could have used the language it did in all these other statutes, too.
But what's your response to his argument when Congress amended the other statute in response to Gwaltney they just didn't adopt this route?

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --Well, by amending the Clean Air Act in 1970... 1990, to say that the... they can sue for a past violation in the event there is evidence of a repeated violation certainly doesn't amend EPCRA.
It only amends the Clean Air Act, or any of the other statutes that use these various formulations in citizen's suits.

United Musical drew strength from the fact that Congress amended the Clean Air Act but not EPCRA to say EPCRA must mean what the citizen's 60-day cure periods mean in 17 other statutes, all 17 of which were cited in a footnote in Hallstrom.
So looking at the case as a whole, looking at the context, we think that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: A later Congress' amendment doesn't necessarily show what the earlier Congress meant, anyway.
I mean--

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --It's as reasonable to think the amendment was meant to change what preexisted as it is to think that it was meant to confirm what preexisted, isn't it?

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: But we don't think there's any likelihood that Congress would have done that without citing any of that in its legislative history of the Clean Air Act.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Stein.

turn.speaker: sanford_m_stein
turn.label: Mr. Sanford M. Stein
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at ten o'clock.
